original_title: 3D Printed Eel Could Cost Less At Scale
original_content:
Be it a matter of cost, principle, or just plain being landlocked, the idea of 3D printed vegan eel over the real deal is quite an attractive development. An Israeli company called Steakholder Foods has introduced this very thing  something they claim is the worlds first plant-based, printed eel.
One thing to note about eel is that they are quite intricately textured, a problem which seems tailored for 3D printing. The company say they achieve similarity through precise layering and a unique combination of materials, which are proprietary. Although the current product is based solely on plant materials, the plan is to incorporate eel cells in the future. Right now, the company is looking to collaborate by providing printers and ink so that participants can create short-term revenue.
While its unclear whether the eel is printed and then cooked, or print-cooked like this chicken, it sure looks tasty. Would you eat printed food? Have you done so already? Let us know in the comments.
title: 「世界初・植物由来の3Dプリント鰻」- イスラエル企業が画期的なプリント食品を紹介
body: イスラエルの会社が、植物由来の3Dプリントウナギを世界初として紹介。質感を再現するために特殊な層積みと素材の組み合わせを使用。将来的にはウナギの細胞も組み込む予定。現在はプリンターやインクの提供で収益化を目指す。プリントしてから調理するかは不明だが、美味しそう。プリント食品を食べたことはある？食べる？コメントで教えてください。
titles: 「世界初・植物由来の3Dプリント鰻」- イスラエル企業が画期的なプリント食品を紹介
